annotation:
In many of Jens Peter's stories about robbers, they actually get away. If they do not manage to get away (JPP 2.01 above), they are in no condition to reveal the location of their fellow robbers. Jens Peter uses this short account as a way to wrap up his stories about robbers hiding out in the woods.

     An interesting feature of this story is the reference to a “svær krat” or thick woods in the telling—south of Amdal Mill, there is a farm noted on maps from the 1880s, named Tykskovgård or “Thick Woods Farm,” even though the woods are no longer there.
danish_manuscript:
I Amdal sønden for Amdals Mølle
mellem Ugilt og Taars skal i ældre Tid 
have været et svært Krat, og der var ogsaa
Røvere. Min Bedsteforældre kunde 
nok huske det Krat og at de gik og tog Folk op.
baade kjørende og gaaende og plyndrede 
dem af. Men de fik aldrig noget rigtig
Ram paa dem.
english_manuscript: In Amdal south of Amdal mill between Ugilt and Tårs there was supposed to have been a thick woods in the old days and there were also robbers there. My grandparents remembered those woods, and they went and took people up there, both those who were driving and walking, and plundered them. But no one ever really got a hold of those robbers.
danish_publication: I Amdal sønden for Amdals mølle mellem Ugilt og Tårs skal i ældre tid have været et svært krat, og der var også rövere. Mine bedsteforældre kunde nok huske det krat, og at de gik og tog folk op der, både kjørende og gående, og plyndrede dem af. Men folk fik aldrig noget rigtigt ram til de rövere.
english_publication: In the old days in Amdal south of Amdal mill between Ugilt and Tårs there was supposed to have been a thick woods and there were also robbers there. My grandparents remembered those woods, and the robbers went and attacked people up there, both those who were driving and walking, and plundered them. But no one ever really got those robbers.
